1BC83F05EB1B45E096DA79AD186B7C5B.description:
Plan and carry out an investigation using a computer-based geographical information tool such
as Google Earth, ArcGIS, or My NASA Data to examine the impact of human activities on Earth’s
surface features.

EC45CF6CF7294885B8D086DE3557D5F4.description:
Design, build, and refine a device to reduce or eliminate the effect of weathering, erosion,
deposition, or other land-surface changes that could be used by the Army Corps of Engineers,
Tennessee Valley Authority, Department of Highways, or other agency to improve the road or
water systems in Tennessee.

F25A0F5252B04C6B846AB5B2262D77EA.description:
Read, interpret, and analyze a combination of ground-based observations, satellite data, and
computer models to demonstrate the interconnectedness of the geosphere, atmosphere,
hydrosphere, and biosphere.

94632411ECCD4613A497967935C6EB93.description: Links Among Engineering, Technology, Science, and Society

CEC66D93A09B4FEEBF9DF0E7673A8655.description:
Evaluate competing design solutions for developing, managing, and utilizing energy and mineral
resources in areas where they are scarce. Compare solutions in terms of environmental impact,
sustainability, and cost.

66005AF8FA494AED985A4B1298EFBB73.description:
Evaluate the evidence and reasoning supporting claims about the impact of human activities on
groundwater quality. The evaluation should include data related to multiple factors (e.g.,
precipitation, topography, porosity, and run-off).

E5F57CB60A8947A0B2EB18CF60D1E0C6.description:
Make and defend a claim based on evidence to describe the formation and future availability of
mined resources (e.g., phosphorous, platinum, and fossil fuels).

C8204CCE62C14ED7B0B1557429FC42E4.description:
Use a topographic map and a geologic map to determine an ideal location for a Tennessee
electricity-generating facility to provide solar, wind, nuclear, hydroelectric, or other
renewable/nonrenewable power.

86750E900E6F458D8BC8B6C009CD8472.description:
Analyze the effect of an earthquake upon the geosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and/or
biosphere, including sphere-to-sphere interactions. Analysis should conclude with an
identification of future research to improve our ability to predict such interactions.

716A741CE91448A6A8CCBE3FC3F86594.description:
Using maps and other data types, predict how plate tectonics cause earthquake activity,
volcanic eruptions, and mountain building.

0080F0B76F0945FDA307696CB2404EB5.description:
Apply scientific principles regarding thermal convection and gravitational movement of dense
materials to predict the outcomes of continued development and movement of lithospheric
plates from their growing margins at a divergent boundary (mid-ocean ridge) to their
destructive margin at a convergent boundary (subduction zone).

742B8DB3003A475ABD695A2386AF86D3.description:
Communicate scientific and technical information to explain how evidence from deep probes
and seismic waves, reconstructions of historical changes in Earth’s surface and its magnetic field,
and an understanding of physical and chemical processes lead to a model of Earth with a hot but
solid inner core, a liquid outer core, a solid mantle, and crust.

624009B2456B4CEDAC529961D3422B1C.description:
Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about man-made and natural threats (e.g.,
mining, pollution, erosion, runoff, floods, and earthquakes) to Tennessee watersheds.

ED19672AC0C146E391A6FC6E496F7902.description:
Design a solution to a complex real-world problem caused by the dynamic nature of rivers and
streams which erode and transport sediment, change their course, and flood their banks in
natural and recurring patterns.

CB576794ED1D4B5FB2D0B920F77982BC.description:
Conduct research, provide a rationale, plan, and conduct an investigation of the properties of
water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes. The rationale should take into
account processes of the hydrologic cycle, including evaporation, condensation, precipitation,
surface runoff, and groundwater percolation, infiltration, and transpiration.

A24558183CBC408699A5D11E432A4657.description:
Develop a model that combines the rock cycle and the carbon cycle, which explains what leads
up to and follows a major volcanic eruption and its effect on carbon storage and fluxes.

F426AE7CA1614BD0A886646C74CF7940.description:
Develop a visual model to illustrate the formation and reformation of rocks over time including
processes such as weathering, sedimentation, and plate movement. The model should include a
comparison of the physical properties of various rock types, common rock-forming minerals,
and continental rocks versus the oceanic crust.

E4F7FCB6587D4C85AF1ED201697B3933.description:
Communicate scientific and technical information about how the dynamic nature of the rock
cycle accounts for the interrelationships among rock and mineral types, and describe how the
total amount of material stays the same throughout formation, weathering, sedimentation, and
reformation.

B3B007CFCE304B018D3353722A303FB5.description: Investigate the structure and geometry of crystals.

1D32A3ED429B422CB59EF2ADB8F93F6A.description: Distinguish between the physical and chemical properties of minerals.

0BA806452AA647048FD0AB7964735675.description:
Classify minerals and rocks on the basis of their physical and chemical properties and the
environment in which they were formed.

3311CF6B2B8245D095F19A840BF33E9E.description:
Create a visual model describing the processes responsible for forming the three rock groups
(sedimentary, igneous, and metamorphic) and explaining their characteristics.

64742DA50C1A471F876B4DB7CD0E9652.description:
Engage in an argument from geoscience data to assert that changes to Earth's surface can create
feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.

815825DD9470468AA17F053BE3198E5D.description:
Analyze surface features of Earth in order to identify geologic processes (including weathering,
erosion, deposition, and glaciation) that are likely to have been responsible for their formation.

5878997944EF47B28C96FFDE89419573.description:
Evaluate the geologic evidence (including index fossils, absolute and relative dating methods,
superposition, and/or crosscutting relationships) used to infer the age of the Earth. Design a
research study to confirm or refute one aspect of such evidence.

0698705AC1604D2BA2444564D32DCBB3.description:
Evaluate evidence used to explain the ongoing changes in the Earth's system over geologic time
due to interactions among the solid Earth, hydrosphere, and atmosphere.

A535E5D1B59A46219762AE7BFBF185BB.description:
Compare and contrast methods for constructing accounts of Earth’s formation, early history,
and/or changes in environmental conditions on Earth over time.
